Oh, this is similar to the flicker effect which is used by some flashlight manufacturers to make the LED from the flashlight flicker 50 times/ sec (50Hz), or so, in order to save/preserve energy from the batteries. If the LED would continuously light when the flashlight is turned on, the LED would use more energy instead of flickering very fast.
With the naked eye, u can't see this effect but if you film the flashlight you will probably notice it more easily. This is also on LEDs panels on the buses where the bus route number is displayed, you will notice this flickering on cameras but not with the naked eye..And examples may continue, such as advertising LED billboards on streets. Yes, making a LED flicker fast enough to trick the eye, can save a lot of energy. Liked the video, best regards from Romania.

You could have saved yourself a plane ticket by simply finding an old CRT monitor or TV set.  It paints the screen the same way the spinning display thing works and relies on persistence of vision to work without flickering.  Also, you can defeat the persistence of vision by moving your eyes.  A rapidly blinking LED that looks like it is on steady will appear as independent flashes if you move the led or your eyes back and forth.  I find this effect very distracting on Cadillac taillights because they use a fairly low PWM frequency to dim the LED taillights.  You can't see this when you look right at them, but when I move my eyes while driving, I see the taillight strobing across my field of view and it attracts my attention.

It might have clarified the eye's role in persistence of vision if Dr. Anstis had pointed out that the retina and the optic nerve are anatomically and functionally part of the brain, and not, as their names imply a sensory end-organ and cranial nerve. It's a subtle distinction, and not intuitive, since the extension of the brain from the occipital cortex to the retina looks grossly like a cranial nerve, but it's not; it's brain. The real structure which is analagous to a cranial nerve is the many synaptic structures which relay the initial rod and cone impulses from the sensory layer deep in the retina, to the more superficial ganglion cells in the nerve fiber layer, which is the terminus of the brain structure mistakenly called the optic nerve. I'm leaving out a lot of explanation for the sake of simplicity, which doesn't help clarity.
But the point is that the retinal nerve fiber layer is brain, not "nerve", and functions as brain, causing persistence of vision. It even gets migraines ("retinal migraine" which is different from the visual aura of classical migraine.)

1:08 It is not your brain but your eyes that made the color. The mechanism is that when a light-sensing cell is being sensing light, its sensitivity is reduced by that light, causing "temporary blindness". This desentization is due to the sensing molecules becoming saturated and thus less reactive. When you then "invert" the picture, this "burned in pattern" causes the optical nerve to transmit color information to the brain which is not really there.

To see how and why this works, get some really colorful picture. Focus on a point and stay focused on that point for 1-2 minutes. Then quickly move your eyes on a black surface. You will see the negative version (inverted colors) of that picture.

There is a trick which causes your brain to perceive motion that does not exist. Unlike this example, this trick actually causes the brain to generate the motion by confusing the "motion tracking circuitry" in your brain to compensate for a nonexistent motion.

Great video, but Persistence of Vision doesn't explain the black and white light house image that appeared in color. If a black and white negative was shown, our brains wouldn't have filled in the color. But like seeing an afterimage when I camera flash goes off, our brains took the color information of the negative and flipped the colors into a color "positive" once they were "backlit" by the black and white image, which stabilized the image in our minds.

comment_text:
Your almost right at 7:20 with your graph, except that it is a sine wave in actuality.
The "persistence" in vision is analogous to a "refresh rate". 2 primary things are going on:
1) There is a finite time a neuron can fire, before that synapse is saturated. The neurotransmitters have to be cleared before firing again.
2) groups of neurons are being evaluated for signal, so averaged. (These groups are voxels, or 3D pixels).

You got embarrassingly close though. Impressive.
(Btw, when the Prof says "eyes" he means brain. This is mostly an occipital lobe activity in humans. Eyes are mostly on-off switching devices. It's almost like binary language, but they aren't really doing much processing. Ok, well just wanted to clear up that shorthand in case anybody was thrown).

Oh yea and one more thing,,   That "Stored Light" is not stored IN THE BRAIN, it is STORED in the 'Pineal Gland'. If you stare at a light in a dark room, then close your eyes and you still see a 'Light Spot' inside your closed eyelid, which lingers and then slowly goes away?? THAT LIGHT AND IT'S LINGERING FLICKER which  YOU SEE, is stored temporarily inside of your Pineal Gland. WHICH IS THEN SENDING that delayed light SENSATION to the brain. That has implications for lighting, too. I noticed while cycling home from a friends house a couple years ago that with my headlight on medium, the tire tread pattern on my front tire was moving slowly backward. A classic strobe effect. Apparently, LEDs work best driven at a certain current - to dim the lights, circuitry just cycles them on and off rapidly. In essence, I was riding in the dark half the time. Which also may be a problem for smart cars - depending on the frame rate of their cameras, they may, or may not see some types of LED lighting as being on.

Thanks.  You just answered a perplexing question I've had for months.  First of all, I only have vision in one eye.  It's not a  problem but occasionally it acts strange.  Each morning before daylight I have coffee on my porch.  Off in the distance, I see a red flashing light from a cell-tower.  It is sort of 'framed' between branches of pine trees.  Unless the wind is blowing, the flash in not interrupted. I've noticed that when I stare at the light, it blinks off then blinks back on in a different place from where I last saw it.  Sometimes the movement is small and can be in any direction from the last spot.  But lately, the movement is some distance from the original spot.  Add to that, I can actually see it move when the light is on.  And when it comes back on, it may or may not be in the same spot as the last flash.  I was beginning to worry that I may have some kind of serious vision problem in my remaining eye and that it might create a dangerous situation while driving.  I feel better after having seen this video.  Like you, I try to learn something new every day.  Thanks to you, I still have many hours left in the day to learn something else.  Love your videos.

One really interesting side effect of persistance of vision is it gives the image motion blur. Which sounds worse than no motion blur, but in fact gives us separate information about movement that a series of perfectly crisp images don't. I'm sure at some stage in our evolution we probably had less POV, but evolution settled on this middle ground between crispness, light sensitivity and motion blur.

Nonsense! It is not the "brain" but simply the bleaching of the different Rhodopsines in the retinal receptor cells, that causes the "false colour image negative" of the Lighthouse island. The brain and optic nerve have nothing to do with it.
Truth is that often times the brain IS a cause for optical illusions.
But most of the time it is already on the retinal level. Especially if you suppress the unconsient "rapid eye movements" that normally prevent the bleaching of the Rhodopsines (Yes, humans have four kinds for red, green, yellow and blue.)

This reminded me of when I was a forestry student and we were covering stereoscopy in photogrammetry. Basically one looked at two ariel photographs taken from slightly different angles through a viewer. From this you get a "3D" image where you can infer "height", allowing you to work out yield from stands of trees. It's also used by the military to assess heights of buildings when looking at targets. What I and one other found was that we couldn't see the "3D" effect at first; I had to "tell"  my brain to allow the image to pop into view. The lecturer said that this was a problem with folks with high IQ's; though I fear he was stroking our ego's on that one.

Actually, Destin, the "made-up color" isn't performed by your brain, but rather, by the changing colors detected by the cones in your retina. The sense of color vanishes when you move your eyes because changing intensities flush the chemical "difference engines" in the cones, thereby erasing all sense of color.

It's the same delta going from inverse color to black and white as it is from a solid neutral gray to a color photo. Again, the eyes have it. It's all in the retina, not the brain.

Our eye cells on the one hand and especially and also our brain (!!!!) 's processing capability is just slow. This all has a "biological"/"biochemical" drag. We are transporting ions across our nerve cells, not really electrons themselves in a free flow like it is the case inside of a conductive metal cable. For the same reason we could see or "create" television in "analogue" times. The same effect makes the former (film-strip based, image-by-image projection, one after the other) "cinema" possible. (otherwise we never were able to see "fluent" images). While an electron ray creates light onto a screen. at one point at one time, an this keeps traveling all over the whole screen. Our brain creates the perception of an image because it can not separate the single "pixel" events from each other. From that point on, the events "blur" or "blend" into each other. The faster something happens, the worse gets this effect. We see a - still flickering when slow - and finally (if fast line- and framerate) steady image. It is us. the people. our own perception of things which are happening at a fast rate. Not the technology initially has this flaw.

Negative afterimages are caused when the eye's photoreceptors, primarily known as rods and cones, adapt to overstimulation and lose sensitivity.

After overstimulation and the eye remains too steady, the photoreceptors that are constantly exposed to the same stimulus will eventually exhaust their supply of photopigment, resulting in a decrease in signal to the brain, then the brain will interpret it as negative afterimage.
If you want to see things in Ultra High-Def color, stare at the inverted image (0:24) for the full amount of time then go to 1:17
And that's why the cameras in studios or during sport-events shooting other TV screens needed to be synchronized.

This also had me wondering. When we look at a wheel of s car/ bike when travelling alongside, we often see the wheel turning in the opposite direction to its momentum, until it starts to slow, and then we see the wheel turn in the direction of movement. It rather indicates that the brain can only process information at a maximum speed, depending on the age / health of the viewer. If this is the case, then surely technology could be tuned to provide the optimum of performance for the user, rather than over expose the viewer to excess levels of information, that their brain doesn't need which in part might trigger stress responses, such as a fit / seizure or simply exhaustion.

Could this time lag depend on the age of the viewer. We all know that the older we get, the slower our processing of information takes, and also with age, our sight deteriorates, hence a person with poorer sight might not benefit from watching HD images, compared with a teenager with better sight, and developed brain might see higher resolution and a flashing image?
A final thought, some medications can speed up the processing of information, would the information they see, be that of a flashing image? In the same way, that some migraines can leave the person "see" a white out, but they ( like myself) can "read" text on a page - my thinking is it's not the eye that sees, but the brain that processes the view, that enables us to "see" the image. Hence an electronic eye could be used to replace an eye, to enable sight, but currently not to the rendering that we consider comparitable to human sight.

The persistence delay is dictated by the conversion time of the light into a chemical them an electrical signal at the retina level, signals that travels through the optic nerve; the signals speed through the nerve and in the brain and the processing time doesn't matter, because the delay is the same for every singe bit of image. The B/W image trick uses the brain function to look into a memory block and assign to an incomplete image the missing component to recreate the complete image based on the previous experiences and images already experienced and stored. Unless I missed it, you didn't explain why the black-and-white version of the photo of the island appeared to be coloured.
Here's my hypothesis: you initially showed it in inverted colours (sky was brown etc.). You told us to look at one fixed spot for a long time. That meant the brown patch of the image was held stationary on one patch of the retina for a long time, so much so that the retina in that patch got tired out. Then you switched from the negative photo (brown sky etc.) to black-and-white. The patch of the retina that had had a long exposure to brown was now suddenly exposed to pale grey (the colour of the sky in the B&W version). Evidently that patch of the retina was "tired" of the brown, and when the patch was replaced by pale grey the retina was ready to react, or over-react, in some way.

if people then brag abbout that "if it would be less than 30 frames per second we would see flickering" and anny gamer with not enough understanding of how those things work would say "but why can i then still see a constant immage if i got less than 30 fps in a game" its cause that fps counter only shows how manny new pictures a second your graphics card can provide for your monidtor to display, but the display will always (ok most of the time) draw those pictures at its discribed refresh rate, so if you only have fps lower than that refresh rate, the frames (pictures by the graphics card) will be drawn several times untill the card gives out another picture, if your monitor has a lower refresh rate than your graphics card can spit out fps it will just drop some frames on the go, like skip every second frame, this could cause unpleasant distortions or other effects as the monitor doesent know what it should display, so there is an option called v-sync that should cap the gpus fps at the monitors refresh rate and give you the best immage your monitor can provide

And now for something really trippy; Do this at night. You need a white piece of paper bigger than your hand. Be ready with a strobe light set to 1 pulse or a camera flash. Turn off the lights. Have a flashlight with you so you can position your hand in front of the paper. Turn off the flashlight and be staring where your hand is in front of the paper, while it's now dark. Pulse the strobe once or use the camera flash, still concentrating on your hand. After the pulse or flash, move your hand away quickly, still staring where your hand was in front of the paper. If done properly, you can still  " see " your hand where it was in front of the paper even though you've moved it away.  ( Getting stoned first helps with this illusion. ) Happy trails !

Your amygdala--a key component of the limbic system, is your emotional control center for fear, and is concerned with memory registration--reacts to perceived threats before your visual processing is complete. Some call this the "amygdala hijack", but it's the activation of the HPA (hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal) axis that is hijacking your rational brain (i.e., the thalamus). This emotional brain activity processes information milliseconds earlier than the rational brain, so in case of a perceived threat, the amygdala act before any possible direction from the neocortex is received. When the amygdala perceives a threat it can lead to that person to react irrationally and destructively. There's three signs to the this: strong emotional reaction, sudden onset, and post-episode realization if the reaction was inappropriate.

As the phenomenon of magnetism is integral with electricity, and human mental activity is electric, it is unsurprising to find that magnetic fields, while not affecting the body’s metabolism to a significant degree, due to the extremely small amount of ferromagnetic material therein, can influence thought itself.

As discovered through MRI imaging, the area of the brain in which evaluations and opinions about others’ beliefs and morality are made is the tempero-parietal junction (TPJ). In 2010 MIT neuroscientists discovered that application of a magnetic field to the right TPJ, by means of a noninvasive technique called transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) temporarily disrupts an individual’s ability to make judgments based upon previously-learned morality.

In effect, pre-indoctrination is suppressed, resulting in the subject’s tending to judge situations more on a discrete cause-and-effect basis. In theory, TMS could be used to condition personnel to make decisions unencumbered by prior moral, social, or ethical indoctrination; and to remove that same protective indoctrination from a hostile individual being interrogated. Your ears do this as well. If you play two different notes into each ear with headphones (Must isolate each ear with headphones) it will realize the tones don't match, it will subtract one frequency from the other and then PLAY you (in both ears) the difference. And if that frequency happens to be outside of your perceptual range, it plays a beat called a binaural beat that is exactly the rate of the frequency difference.

Example: Play 80Hz in one ear and play 70 Hz in the other. Your brain will subtract the difference and play your frequency back as a beat that is in time with the 10Hz difference, since the 10Hz tone is out of range of hearing.

I don’t know whether you have heard about this or not, but on the off chance that you haven’t, I’m going to repeat it to you. Scientists did an experiment where they placed an oscilloscope on the optic nerve of a Frog and they dangled a bug in front of the Frog. And the oscilloscope showed the the output from the eye that resulted from the frog seeing the bug. They then dangled an object that was not significant to the frog … a stick … in the Frogs field of vision. And the oscilloscope showed NO output whatsoever. The Frog literally DID NOT SEE THE STICK AT ALL! It may as well have been invisible. So what was responsible for this? Was it the optic nerve or the eyeball that was filtering out the output from the eye that was not significant to the Frog? What process of evolution could possibly have resulted in a vision system that filtered out objects that were not significant to its owner?

The eye has a feature to enhance vision aquity during low light. This is a kind of AGC or Automatic gain control. This happens with the single colors too. When you concentrate on a scene without moving the focus, the colors cause the eye to scale back on the gain to that color or combination of colors. When you remove the color, the eye sees the opposite color because the eye has scaled back the gain of the previous colors and has full gain of the previous absent colors.

This is an after image effect created by your eye/brain averaging what you see.  The first image is coloured but inverted.  After images are inverted from the inversion.  When you change the inverted image to black and white, you see the after image with an inversion of the inversion.  And, for a brief period of time, the black and white image has colour, until the after image fades.

hey @smartereveryday can I add two things? 1- the difference between 30 fps and 25 fps is because of the general AC net fluctuation ( Europe 50 Hrz / US 60 Hrz ) This is why the US has 30fps and Europe has 25fps...  * the human eye can make a moving image at around 25 fps) So the invention of the TV could do two 'fields' (2 fields make one frame) based on a positive pulse in ONE AC round. (one upper field / one downfield)  2- the thing that makes his 'round projector' really cool is the fact that the LED at the outside spins relatively faster than the inner one. And so the freq of 'flash'  of the outer ones (from the centre to tip)  must be delayed (exponentially by the use of PI) up. UNLESS you will meet the minimum requirement of the eye / Brain. The eye has so many little tricks that make the world look the way it does. It is unbelievable. This visual delay comes from how we actually see light. The photoreceptors in our eyes are chemical to electrical. Photons create a chemical response in the rods and cones in a biological chemical called rhodopsin which gets converted to the electrical impulse to the brain. But the receptor takes a finite amount of time to recover from the stimulation. It's why that first illusion you did works. The receptors have been stimulated by looking at photos of a certain wavelength consistently over a period of time, so they are overstimulated and take 10 to 30 seconds to fully recover... but during that time they are still sending the impulses to the brain so it thinks it is still "seeing" those colors. Overlayed on a grey image the brain filters the inverse colors into the greens and blues.

Ever looked suddenly at a clock and it seems like the second-hand pauses for a little bit longer? You're not imagining that. When you first look at something moving periodically like a second-hand... your brain can't be certain that it saw the motion so it drops a few frames of the motion making it look like the second hand paused. The delay before you see it is made up of 3 things, first the transition time from the rod/cone cells to the brain along the optic nerve second the brain processing time and 3 the actual time for chemistry in the rod/cone cells to create an electrical pulse from light.

The persistence comes mostly from how long it takes the rod/cone cell to stop triggering nerve impulses after the stimulus is removed.

POV isn't so much a mechanical issue of the eye as it is a neurological one. Our subconscious mind is responsible for the instantaneous processing of incoming data from all of our senses. If it didn't have a way of delaying all this sensory feedback and deciding on what's important we'd very simply be overloaded and go insane quite literally. Our brains are constantly discarding virtually all of the sensory data we're constantly receiving at every moment of every day. It's only when we choose to focus on something that the subconscious mind passes along the data. The limitations of POV is due to the fact that your mind is still working on filtering out a ton of other data as it's passing along the requested stuff, and that's your delay.  It's also why ones perceptions are so drastically altered with the use of psychadelic drugs. Perception is reality, so to speak.

Back in the late 70's I was watching the big laser at LURE Observatory (Mt Haleakala, Maui, Hawaii) shooting at the moon. I commented to the chief scientist that their measurements would be wrong because the speed of light in Hawaii is a bit "laid back" -- about 500 mph. He gave me a strange look, but I took him outside. You could undeniably see the flashes of light streaking out at a very perceptible speed. He was actually stumped by that observation.
The effect is caused by the response time of your photopic and scotopic vision. The bright light exiting the telescope registers immediately in your photopic vision, while the faint light further out takes longer, giving the clear impression that you can "see" the speed of light.
I also had a HP-35 calculator (with a red LED display). I noticed that in dim light (where you can barely see the calculator itself) if you move it quickly in circles, the numeric display will seem to move "outside" of the calculator. Again, for the same reason. This is response time rather than POV. David Harris, University of Hawaii

Years ago I figured out that if I looked at the strobe light of a radio tower in the distance, with my eyes locked forward, and shook my head, I'd see 5 or 6 dots of light each time the strobe lit off. As best I can figure, that's the Raster Rate of my eyes to my brain. So if the strobe duration is say (30 milliseconds) and I see 5 dots of light, it means that every 6 milliseconds or so my eyes send a signal to my brain. I don't know how long strobes go for, but you get the idea. I've googled it, and so far, I haven't found anything that explains it better. Your thoughts?

Well. This guy seems to love explaining dead-simple things as if they're so amazing and hard to understand... Really, persistence of vision is pretty common knowledge. The colours thing at the start is due to your eyes adjusting to colour. You can stare at an inverted colour picture and then look at a white wall, and you'd see a "ghost-like" picture in correct colours.

01:10 - Actually, this is quite normal reaction of neural system, where detection of the certain color is compensated in order to reset the "receivers" - almost like Newton's law in regard to action-reaction, hence, our brain can "see" red color by "generating" the "green force". If we spent longer time looking at certain color it will cause prolonged "compensation" effect, hence, we do not need black and white picture to be able to see true colored picture - white paper would be enough, or we can just close our eyes.
More or less, and other senses are working on the same principle, i.e., in case of wearing the hat, permanent sensation sent to brain, by the time will be neglected (why wasting the time - mechanism), some people are desperately trying to find a hat, that is on top of their head. Luckily, we have mirror(s) in our house.

A couple of years back I was working with a 120Hz monitor with bright sunlight in the background and I sat there and from 1 moment to the next the screen started to go off on off on off on etc etc I blinked a couple of times rubbed my eyes and looked at it again and well there is was I was able to see the screen refresh rate 120Hz monitor refreshes its image 120 times per second but I did not just see the 120 I also was able to see the black frame LCD puts in between frames to clear the screen and prevent burn in.
Thats why I am pretty sure if you would look at this device with a full brightness sun in the background you would see it flicker like crazy.

The 1st silent films were 18 frames per sec. That's too slow for eye persistence to smooth out. They later showed those films at 24 fps so they didn't flicker but the motion sped up. That's why you see those old Chaplin films moving too fast. Digital technology has now corrected for this.

Thanks for this. I guess you will be aware that the visual persistence phenomenon was used by John Logie Baird when he invented his mechanical television. His machine used a spinning wheel with holes in it along a radial trajectory (a spiral) that was illuminated from behind. Baird used a previously known scanning disc system invented by  Paul Gottlieb Nipkow in 1884. Baird's mechanical television made it possible to transmit a live image as electrical pulses in a wire, so that it could be reconstructed some distance from the camera, using his spinning disc. The image that was seen was made possible by the visual persistence phenomenon that you explain here.

*it's called "After Discharge" ,
neurons in our eyes continue to discharge signals to brain , even after the stimulus (image) disappears !
*it's caused by one of the following causes :
1. accumulation of calcium ions inside the neuron for a while , which makes action potentials in spite of disappearing of the stimulus .
2. some types of neuron arrangement in which the 1st neuron sends the signal to a 2nd neuron which sends the signal to a 3rd neuron ,
so the signal is still being sent , in spite of disappearing of the image .

If I remember correctly - the island.... you stare at the island for a time - and the individual cones in your eyes de-sensitise depending on the brilliance of the given colour - i.e. if an item was red, then the red cones desensitise. If you then show white you will see the inverted colours (i.e. the correct colours) because instead of seeing white, you see (in the example above) white with the red part of it desensitised. You can easily prove this by looking at a coloured ball - then at a while page - you'll see the opposite colour for an instant - so to answer your question - this is not the brain but a mechanical property of the eye. Because you showed a grayscale image with no colour bias, for a short while the colours were biased to the opposite of the colour image you'd originally shown.

Simple example - assuming your eyes have red, green and blue sensors.... if you look at a blue light for ages.... then at a white sheet, for a while, as the blue is desensitised, you'll be inclined to see yellow (the red and green together).

This mechanism helps along with the iris in allowing us to see a huge dynamic range - it also helps us to ignore strong colour tints after a while. It is also part of the reason why the camera never shows us what we actually saw because camera sensors do not work like that at the individual element level.

I think I figured out what happens. First of all, just try another "experiment": stand still and look at a point in front of you; it may be in the room you are in, or outside... what is important is that there is nothing moving. After a minute or so, you will notice that your vision tends to "blank out"; if you're not so good at staring at a single point, margins of objects will start showing up in a weird way. if you move, everything gets back to normal.

I think this is the remnant of some kind of ancestral functionality: whether we were predators or preys, we needed to discern animated things from inanimated. (do you remember Jurassic Park's T-Rex? "... if you don't move it can't see you!!!").
In particular, things coming, appearing are most worth noticing...

Now, one step forward: this experiment exploits this functionality and actually makes our brains delete the negative components of a picture (as explained before), so when the picture does not change but its colours (they disappear) or brain is tricked: it noticed that PART of the signals coming from the retina that change, and it starts "showing" it; but what changes? I suppose that the disappearing signals from the cones that are capturing the negative colours are not as important as the new signals coming from all the other cones. In a sense, the brain focuses on signals from the cones that had been inactive till then, and gives us a positive picture of the island.

I realise that my hypothesis is not fully developed, but I think it hits the right path to follow to explain this case...
The rods and cones in your retina make you see color after being stimulated by an opposite  color

If you were wondering how the island at the beginning worked, this is how. When you stare at the image, the cells in your eyes that see color are being used, as you keep looking at the inverted image, the cells that are being used in your eyes to see the inverted image get tired. As a result, the cells that are not tired are the colors that the picture is made up of. So, for example, if you looked at a bright magenta picture for 25-30 seconds, and then looked away, you would see green. This is because the red and green cells in your eyes are used to see magenta as you can see here on this color wheel: https://www.d.umn.edu/~mharvey/colorwheel.jpg The only cells left that aren't tired out are the green cells, this is why you see green. Now, if you noticed, green is on the opposite side of the color wheel from magenta. This means that if you stare at a bright color and then look away you will always see the inverse of it, this is why the image is inverted. The grayscale image just helps with the image "background" or shading. So all the image is doing its taking advantage of your color receptors in the back of your eye getting tired, and using that to color a picture. It's pretty cool when you think about it. :D

The island is an example of a negative afterimage, caused (it is believed) by desensitization of your eyes' photoreceptors after relatively long exposure to a single color stimulus. Persistence of vision (POV), the basis of a propeller- or POV display like the second example, is a completely different phenomenon that acts over a very short term, and while it is probably the result of a similar chemical mechanism, is different, most strikingly in that it takes place over microseconds. You can't see the negative afterimage with the LEDs because they come back around and light up before your brain has time to see the afterimage.

If you watch the prop clock in a dark room for a minute or so and then turn the lights on and look at a blank piece of paper, you'll see colored spots where the LEDs were... that's the same phenomenon as the B&W photo. If you want to see a true positive afterimage, pop a camera flash in a completely dark room. You'll see everything just as it was when the flash went off; only for several seconds.

The main takeaway from this lesson should be that your eyes do not see "frames" or have a "fps limit."

This concept applied to film projectors in movie theatres. The projector would show 24 frames per second, but each frame was shown twice with equally spaced dark spaces between each flash of the picture. This resulted in 96 distinct  "images" per second. One of the dark spaces was also used to mask the transition between frames, otherwise it would be a constant blur.

Fun fact:   ≈25fps is used for European broadcast TV, but guess what, we can view even slower without gaps -  For ex: American films/movies ≈ 24fps (actually 23.976fps).  We are so used to seeing movies like this that it's unsettling for most people to watch movies in 30, 48, 50, or 60fps.  It's fine for tv shows to be 30 (29.97) because we in the US have grown accustom to this. The moral of the story is if you want to shoot a video to get the "film" look go for 24 fps, but having high dynamic range and higher res will help a great deal too.

The moving LED persistence of vision effect has absolutely nothing to do with the static image demo at the beginning of your video, you do know that, don't you?

From what I recall, the color reversal effect for the static image is related to recovery of the light sensitive dyes in the retina's cone cells, not to any processing by the brain. Small movements of the eye help the dyes to recover by rapidly changing the exposure of individual cells to differing light colors. Staring fixedly prevents that recovery and the color reversal is caused by the altered response of the selectively exhausted pigments.
So is persistence of vision intentional in our biology or a side effect?  After all, our ancestors weren't worried about watching 30fps movies.

I noticed that the picture at the beginning was a negative image of a coloured version of the cliff. I think this is the main reason why so many people see green and blue.

The negative is burned into a persons retinas temporarily and when the person looks away from the image they see the negative colours of the negative image.

That means that the person will see a green hill and a blue ocean.
If you take a snapshot of the initial picture and put it through a negative filter you'll see the correct colors.

It would make three scans of the monitor with each filter in front of the monitor. The point is, the display looked just like that. Varying intensities of points of light. Then that was recorded by a film camera focused on the monitor. Then print the resulting negative normally

Very simple way to demo persistence of vision: you can point a laser pointer at a wall and it makes a dot. Then you can shake it rapidly back and forth and it looks like a line or an ellipse. But you know it's just a dot.

I work in television system design. We have a saying: "Television doesn't have to work, it only has to look like it works." We use all kinds of psychovisual tricks to reduce the amount of data we need to send. The videos you upload are compressed, like a zip file, but not really, because a zip file can be de-compressed perfectly back to the original file, but not your videos. We call this "lossy" compression, and we get away with it because we know what you can't see.

We know that you can't see detail in something that moves, so we don't send moving detail. We know that you only have high resolution vision for black and white, not color, so the color part is sent at half resolution. We know that you will not be able to notice flaws in a busy part of the image (like a crowd in a stadium) compared to, say, the sky, so we don't send accurate data in the busy parts of the image. The tricks go on and on.

A zip file will typically reduce a file size by 2:1. Using lossy compression we can reduce a video from 8+8+8 (24) bits per RGB pixel to about 0.17 bits/pixel (almost 150:1!). All because we know what you can't see, and television doesn't have to work, it only has to look like it works.

When you see a video that is "pixelated" (we call this "blocky" because the squares you see are actually blocks of pixels) -- you are seeing the compression tricks being overused to the point where you are no longer fooled. But usually we can fool you into thinking it's working perfectly.

Here's a fun persistence of vision experiment.  Take an old camera with an electronic flash into a completely dark room.  Give your eyes a minute to adjust.  Hold one hand in your lap and stare at it.  You can't see it because it's dark but just look where your hand is.  Fix your eyes there.  With the other hand point the camera at your lap and trip the shutter.  The light from the flash will overwhelm your eyes but keep them fixed.  You will see an afterimage of the whole room with your hand in your lap.  Wait a few seconds then slowly move your fingers.  The image you see will go through a transition while your brain sorts out the conflicting information it's receiving from your eyes and the nerves in your hand.  Eventually it will decide your eyes are lying and blur the image.

Okay, so the lighthouse island inversion did not work on me at first. When it inverted, I saw only gray. So, I backed it up and tried it again. I thought maybe my eyes jumped, or I unconsciously blinked, or something. I was already aware of the principle involved, and predicted mentally what you were probably going to do, so I knew it was supposed to work. However, I did not consciously know what color was supposed to be on the island.

The second time, I did see the green, but for only about a second, and then it switched to grays, while I was still staring at the lighthouse, before my eyes moved to the edge of the island. It was as if a physical switch switched it from green to gray. I have engaged in such experiments before, but it was some years ago.

So, I am wondering why my brain did not process the green longer. Is it because, my brain was predicting what you were going to do, or maybe I have some kind of color processing deficiency?

I have never noticed any problem with colors before, except that as I have gotten older, I have noticed my night vision is starting to get a little worse. A young friend of mine was amazed that I could not distinguish certain colors on a building that was lit only by a distant streetlight at night. I wonder if that is a clue?

Cool explaining video.The same you could see the last 90 years in every CRT Television where never more than one "pixel" at a time glows.
Exactly all "pixels" of the first pixel-row glow one after another, than all pixels of row 3 one after another, than all of row 5 and after all odd numbered rows finished with that, all pixels from second row start, than row 4, row 6, row 8..
If all pixels glowed one time you have a full picture. But never more than one glowing pixel at a time. Your brain makes the rest and lets you see the full picture,
A CRT TV completes a full picture around 25 times a second.

First image was a negative of a colour original, not black and white(!). Your brain recognized it and it was said to you. Thus when the lighthous changed from black to white, your brain reconstructed the rest (not focused part) of the image under the same principal providing you with the oposite colours(!), not shades of grey. This would not work, if the original image was black and white negative. Our brain is not cheating, but helping.

Be careful, a lot of the science behind "persistence of vision" is considered bunk even though it's still taught. The human visual system doesn't see in frames, it's continuous as your demonstration illustrates, but it's often discussed in these type of terms because of animation, films, displays. The human eye can detect very small amounts of light as sensory data, but how well the brain decodes that information into it being something meaningful seems to be incredibly complex and not necessarily well understood as of yet.

This concept of our bains averaging what we see also applies to the way we perceive sound. When you listen to your favorite song file you're actually hearing micro blips of sound anywhere from 24k times per second to 192k. For audio this is called sample rate. Better audio interfaces can record and process at higher sample rates.Thats why when you stretch audio to much you start to hear the gaps, just like if you used slo-mo but did not have the frame rate to match you would see gaps between the images.

Why don't we explain it easier. The stuff that makes up the retina has a long memory which holds patches of light information even if the source of light disappears.

Here is a good one. TV cameras have this memory too, so if an object is placed in between a camera and a monitor and an object placed in between then what the camera is photographing will appear on the monitor behind the object, If the system is perfectly lined up then if we take away the object very quickly then due due to the memory or persistence of vision of the pixels on the Monitor the image will be retained without the object in between. The fact that we have MEMORY in most devices we have managed to go a long way. We should all be pleased that Memory retains the shapes of toilets, cups, cars, homes, books, photos and that little short memory in our eyes help us to see continuous pictures.

That was really cool. I'm pretty sure I know how it worked though: the black and white image had no color, but the inverted image did, only opposite of what it should be. When it was switched, either you brain knew what the opposite color was supposed to be, and made you see it where it wasn't, or the color receptors in your eyes were leaving an opposite-color signal due to what they had been picking up, like seeing an afterimage when staring at a bright light or picture. That seems logical, except that there is no delay; if you don't focus on the lighthouse, or if you look away at any random time, you wont see anything, where eye receptors should take a certain amount of time to switch (and in that case, we'd get that effect every time an image was switched). I know it's not just power of suggestion, because I tried it several times, and it worked every time. Definitely a physical causation.

Technically this is not correcty what you're saying at 8:10 The video can be recorded at lower or higher framerate,we will still see no flickering if the playback device (the monitor) is set up to display the picture at 60Hz (less should work fine too). You can adjust youtube settings (the wheel icon in the right bottom corner) to set playback speed of that video to 1/4 of its normal speed (this will be 30FPS / 4 = 7.5 frames per second) and you will still see no flickering bacause your monitor is at 60Hz. However if you manage to reduce your monitor frequency to 7.5Hz you'd see it going black for a fraction of a second before displaying you next picture of a "slide-show" the video will turn into.

I have been diagnosed with early stage glaucoma and have always worn glasses to correct for myopia. Lately I have begun "seeing" random dark shapes in peripheral vision, which are clearly artefacts of optic nerve degeneration or some such. The interesting thing is that sometimes my brain rationalises them post facto as animals, so I have the momentary impression a bat just flew past, or a cat ran past, or something. Occasionally it even insists they are human presences. It seems to me this goes a long way towards explaining ghost stories and the like.

To contrast and compare ... kinda ... I'd like to point out the newer HDTVs that ADD frames to video and make the motion look "smoother". It actually drives me nuts, especially since I'm an animator. To ME, I feel like I'm looking at a lie. My brain refuses to believe it. My theory is, since the TV process adds frames that normally are not there, so there are no blurred images where fast motion occurs. So, the brain knows something is not right and everything feels cheap and slippery. I hate those TVs and what's even worse is when no one sees what you see ... like my dad. All he sees is what he thinks is a "clearer"image. All I see is a molested image that was never the original, intended product from the creators. Total BS.

comment_by: Senator Dr. Patrick McCusker III, Esq.
comment_text: Persistence of vision is actually the way we perceive motion on a standard TV. Old CRT TVs would draw half a picture and then alternate the other half of the picture to create a series of pictures we see as motion. Progressive scanning (the p in 1080p) shows the entire image at one time. Still though, all TV is a flip book style presentation of still images. Great video!

The color portion is not your brain doing it. It is your retina cells called cones responsible for colors that are being over sensitized by staring for a long period. If you stare at a red dot on a white paper for 30 seconds and then remove the dot, you will continue to see it for a few more seconds only in green. That is because only the cones responsible for red were over sensitized and function less, so when you continue to look at the white paper, but without the red dot all you cones (red, green and blue) are supposed operate to see white but the red ones are too tired to operate and therefore you see the negative (i.e. the opposite) of red which is the green. In other words, only the cells that are not tired operate in that area where it used to be red and is now white. This has nothing to do with the brain.

I can tell you what is happening, when you flick it from inverted colour, to black & White. Its called Neuro Synthesia. Your unconscious learned brain 1] Knows a generalisation of colour to particular natural forms, like grass, rock, water, sea, sky. And automatically fills in anomalies when they happen. Like your blind spot. 2] Your unconscious brain knows oppositions, in many things, like colour, geometry, form. So when you replace an invert colour with black and white, you brain will automate an approximation of what a natural form of colour should be.  This is demonstrated perfectly with your lighthouse on the mountain. Because your inverted colour photo, was of the full colour photo, not the black an white version. But when you flicked the inverted colour to black & White, Only base colours [as explained in 1] ] appeared and only at 50% transparency, which is the exact same transparency of imagery and colour your brain produces when day dreaming, Not the full mixed spectrum. Only once you show the full colour picture, does your become immediately and consciously aware of the colours it missed without even thinking about that anomaly, cause it does it itself.  Your question is it the eyes doing this or your brain, is a silly question. You eyes only collect information, your Brain processes it. Though your eyes will only take in information the same speed your brain processes it, that is your delay. But that can counteracted. Morphine or Adrenaline can exponentially speed up your neurons 10 fold. The faster your neurons are activating, the more information they collect. Being frightened speeds up your neurons, and your brain can remember a lot more than it usually would. This can also make time literally feel like it is slowing down.

The one issue I have with this video is that Destin says that if it wasn't 30fps we would begin to see flicker. That wouldn't happen because the frames aren't displayed and then removed before showing the next frame as a film projector does. What actually happens is that one frame is shown and then instantly replaced by a new frame so that there is always a frame visible. If you lower the frame rate, the video would just begin to look choppy and unnatural and at a certain point, our brains wouldn't detect it as motion at all, but as a slideshow of images.

It's cool to see the science behind this phenomenon. I actually have a light wand made by Sweet Apple Amperes that does the same thing, though you have to physically swing it around. Even though you can't physically rotate it 25 times per second, you can still see the images quite clearly, and when you hold it still, you can see how it flashes seemingly random lights, just like the one in the video.

I used to be a projectionist at a movie theatre, which is where I learned about persistence of vision. Projection is mostly done digitally now, but when we used film, the projectors had a shutter which masked the frame changes by briefly cutting out the light as the change happened to prevent motion blur, or "ghosting," as we called it. I don't know about digital projection, but with traditional 35mm film, half the time you spend watching a movie is actually spent watching a blank screen.

We don't see flashing led's due to a phenomenon called retinal persistence; meaning before you loose that piece of info inside your retina, there comes another image, and voilá :)
The data rate need to actually see this is around 24 pictures per second and that's why cinema has that amount of images; should we have not that "thing" in our retina, we would see just flashing kind of "photos". 24 fps is not a random value; in fact earlier movies runned between 8 and 12 fps, depending on your speed on hand lever action cameras. With the advent of 8 mm cameras (before video went democratic, so to speak...) we had 18 or 24 fps (people used 18 to gain some time in those 3 minutes reels); that's why we see a curtain when trying to capture a projected image with a video camera (30 fps in NTSC and 25 in PAL). So, cinema industry tried out to figure what should be the higher value per second (to get better quality) but without still frames seeing by.
Audition has different reaction: we hear a click of around 5 ms (old vinyl records had lots of it), but we don't hear a gap of 5 ms; the first type of sound filters used this particularity to eliminate some sort of clicks, cracks and what so ever :)

Cheers from Portugal :)

OK +SmarterEveryDay , without reading all the comments or even finishing the video here is what is happening with the light house picture.

The reversed image is COLOR and our eyes get color fatigue staring at a single point so that when the image goes away we see the REVESE of that image but ONLY as a ghost image. When that GHOST image is laid over the black and white image it colors it in. SO we are in fact SEEING the color, but only as an after image. And once we move our eyes to a different spot the after image no longer lines up and the color fatigue in our eyes fades pretty quickly.

Still, cool stuff!

Dustin, you should try pointing your high-speed camera at an older TV using a cathode ray tube and perhaps at a modern LCD display.  You may have to adjust the contrast to get something interesting.  These displays are also actually scanning or updating one pixel at a time but the refresh rate is usually so high that few people notice.  In the case of the older TV, the pixel is written by an electron beam that strikes a phosphor location that emits light.  The beam is steered by an electromagnet attached to the rear of the glass cathode ray tube.

I have thought about this many times in the past. With the opening shot of the reversed lighthouse, I get the persistence of vision thing going on there, but would add one thing you didn't mention. It has appeared to me before that when you focus on one thing for a long period of time, two things happen. First, you get the persistence of vision, as you suggested. The second thing which happens is you get a negative image built into the persistence of vision. So, if you are looking at something which is black, the persistence of vision would be white and visa-versa. Greens become reds, blues become orange, etc. This was the reason we were seeing the lighthouse picture in color when you reversed the color map (well actually, you flipped it and made it monotone) after we stared at it for a while. I really noticed this happen once when I went in a friends submarine (yes, a yellow submarine). We were under the surface of a very clear lake in Montana. As you got deeper, the color outside (shining into the sub through the windows) became more and more green. Our eyes compensated for this, but I didn't notice until we got back to the surface. Once there, EVERYTHING had a pink hue to it. It was an awesome realization. Again, I don't know if it's actually our eyes adjusting for the color, or if it's the brain which does it. Either way it makes for some awesome science.

Great video by the way ... and Lynda.com is an awesome resource!

Hey Destin!
I've always been a science enthusiast so I've read before about the persistence of vision.
But watching your video, now that I'm in medical school, it rings a bell. The pattern you show at the 6:55 mark is actually the action potential of the neuron cell.
So, answering your initial question: The thing is not going on in the eye, or the optic nerve, or the brain... It's happening at all three of them!! It is a direct consequence of using ions and pumps to transfer information instead of electrons like a computer.
My question now is: Can we enhance it? Did we stop at this frequency because we have a processing power limitation or just because it was enough and we didn't have to evolve more to see continuously?

+SmarterEveryDay: First of all, I really like your videos, but I have to add a bit: Nope, you're wrong there on some numbers.
Even if the video was less than 30FPS we would still see it. We actually would, if I remember correctly, still see it from 14 to 17FPS, the rate is subjective.
But why is the number 25 FPS and 30 FPS used so much?

I'll leave you that as a challenge... or should I hint it up?

A small hint, 25 FPS is historically the number that you get in Europe, and our electricity runs at 50 HZ.

30FPS is what you get in the US, your electricity runs at ~60HZ.

Ok, going to wikipedia I see that they do not make those reasons obvious, so the answers are: NTSC (US television system) and PAL (Europe's one) run at those rates, in part because of practicalities of frequency of the electricity. Although that part isn't explained in most of the wikipedia articles that I saw.

Just one omission in the video: There is refresh rate of the display vs. refresh rates of the video. The video refresh rates are increased in order to make the movements more "life-like". The display refresh rates would be visible if too low, however too low video refresh rates wouldn't cause "flicker" as the new frames are just drawn over the old ones: this as opposed to old cinema and film where the flicker was caused by the film frame changing effect over the projector's backlight. In the past people have complained about "too high" refresh rates when 48 fps was tested for the first time (so called "HFR" movies) and the 30 fps seem to be a compromise of multiple factors, including the storage space required. (In the past, also playing a role were the cinema screen material and the amount of time it takes for the CRT fluorescence material to turn completely black (so there is also delays in those). Slowness of the CRT fluorescence material was one reason why very high refresh rates were usually not needed).

the only reason you saw color is because if you stare at the inverted color of the island for a long time, your brain will see the complimentary color when it is removed. that means if you start at the yellow (red+green) sky for a long time, you will see blue. if the inverted picture had a green sky, you would have seen (blue+red) a purple sky when you show the grey picture. it had nothing to do with your brain filling in the sky as a blue.

But Dustin, you never came back to the island colour illusion to explain to your viewers that--if they keep the image frames perfectly 'registered' (in printers' lingo)--they will perceive colour when you switch to the black and white image because their brain is combining an inverted-colour after-image with a B&W current image to 'see' the colour photo. When they 'de-register' the frames by shifting their gaze (and the after-image fades) the colour illusion vanishes.

Destin, this was a pretty cool visual effect, but one can't help but look at the entire image. The image is a an inverted color photo (negative) of an island. Being that it's inverted, your brain somewhat interprets this "negative" and tells me that it's a color photo. So technically you're not being truthful, because if the image was a black & white negative, everyone would know that they're going to see a black & white image and color would have never been seen by the brain. This said, I think the brain can somewhat interpret a color negative and say, "I'm about to see color." Therefore when you exposed it in B&W, my brain inverted those to the interpreted color, and we saw color where there wasn't any. Although this was "the hand is quicker than the eye" trick, it was pretty cool and "yes" it works. I'll have to try it in the office tomorrow on some of my colleagues.

I would note that animation (at least classical 2D cel animation) is generally much lower framerate than that. The standard set by Disney is 12 fps, where they will print to film by doubling up 2 exposures of every frame for a 24 fps roll, and we all remember how fluid it looked back in the day. Most CG animation is done at the full 24 fps, and with the 180-degree shutter and all, but there are some examples of animation for TV done at rates as low as 6 fps, but many of these have variable framerates where the animation can ratchet up to 24 for a spell and then back down to 8 for some bits and then 16 for something else, and 6 for a slow-action scene... basically, it's a budgeting measure wherein they reserve their time and efforts where it's crucial and cut corners elsewhere.

Of course, being able to see something as smooth is not the same thing as being able to only collect that amount of information. The latency of that moving average doesn't mean your occipital lobe isn't still reading in more, so you can see the difference between high and low framerates. Also, that little bit of a trough that occurs in the waiting between repetitive light emissions is why people can sometimes be sensitive to the flicker that happens in CRTs due to the phosphor fade between refresh cycles (at least until you refreshed at higher than 85 Hz or so). This was also related in some sense to the principle behind Unipixel's (now apparently dead) TMOS display concept where they basically controlled color and/or intensity by time-limited control of a per-pixel shutter for the cycling RGB LEDs... but you needed to refresh pretty fast to avoid rainbowing effects

The eye is integrated into a neural network which excels at pattern recognition. Persistence of vision is responsive to the fact that there is a coherent image to recognize.  If the image were gibberish, or there were a dynamic pattern that required faster time-resolution (think motion tracking), the neural net will adjust the refresh rate on the fly.  This adjustment can occur at any and every layer, including the vision cortex, the optic nerve, the retina, as well as the muscles of the eye.  Practice will optimize the system for particular patterns and activities.

Also, our eyes only transfer to the brain the "light difference". In other words, if you make your eyes stationary, then after about a minute your vision will start backing out (try not to blink). But as soon as you move your eyes, everything get's back to normal.
This is done to make the signals transferred to the brain to be less susceptible to electromagnetic noise and make it more energy efficient. So actually, our brain "integrates" the image that the eyes are sending to it to recreate a model of our surrounding. Since our eye is constantly moving, this seeing only the difference design is not creating any issues.

This is why you see color in the black and white image of the island, because your eyes are sending the difference between the inverted image and the gray image for a short while.

The Texas Instruments Digital Micromirror Device, used in many projectors, has used this concept for years.  White light of a projector is sent through a spinning RGB & clear color wheel.  It then bounces off a mirror and out the lens.  The mirror is actually made of individual mirrors (1 mirror per pixel) on 2 axis movement.  The on position of the mirror reflects light through the lens.  The off position reflects light to the side and not out of the lens.  These micro-mirrors stay on longer or shorter for more intensity.  Also, they are timed with the spinning color wheel to give the perception of different colors.  Viewers are being presented with an imperceptible storm of Morse code color - dots and dashes of different time duration synced with color wheel.  The viewer just sees and image.

Destin, this is also the effect you get with what's called Pulse-Width-Modulation. An LED turns off and on much faster then we'd normally be able to see it, but the longer it's on, the brighter our brains will perceive that average. It's used in LED lights, and OLED tv screens (where the Red, Green, and Blue colors are controlled independently).

Ok so Destin. This is a really cool video, and I have a really cool experiment that anyone can do at home. A long while ago my bedroom was one that would go pitch dark without the light on. On a whim I was flicking the light on and off as any youngster likes to do, but I noticed something amazing. I noticed the delay/auto fill thing the brain does.

SO!!! Find a pitch black room, stare at 1 and only 1 spot in the room. Flick the light on and off about once every second about 10-15 times. Keep staring for another 10 seconds! If you stared at the same spot then you should see something amazing like the concept in this video. It seems to work better with a higher contrast, so a dim light wont work.

It's as though your brain recreates the room in your vision as it last saw it, but in a dark "burned" in kind of way like you see on old CRT monitor/tvs. It takes a bit for your brain to recreate so wait a bit before looking away. If 10-15 times aren't enough you can do more. Give it a try!

The reason you see the inverted colors in the photo trick has to do with the way the cones of our eyes work. The cones on the retina are what detect colors. They work best when being stimulated at constantly varying levels, which typically happens as we move are eyes around. When a particular photoreceptor gets stimulated at the same level for an extended period of time, it "tires out" and becomes less sensitive (its why your eyes can get tired when you stare at similar images all day like a computer screen). So, when you stare at a particular point on the backward color picture, the cones that are being stimulated start to tire out. Then, when the monochrome image replaces it, the cones don't correctly detect the even color distribution (which normally produce grey tones) that are coming in. Because each cone was tired out of the inverted color, it tends to perceive the opposite color on the monochrome image, which happens to be the original color. You'll notice that if you avert your eyes for only a few moments after the shift, then return them, the illusion all but disappears, as you've "refreshed" your cones by changing their view.This is also why you'll often perceive ghosts of bright lights that you've seen when you close your eyes.You can try further experiments with this. If you can find a small, sharp feature to focus on in the room you're in, and force yourself to stare precisely at it, not letting your gaze shift at all, after awhile your vision will start to blur and grey out and it will become uncomfortable and the strong compulsion to shift your gaze will become hard to resist. This is because the cones are tiring out and becoming less effective.

One common misconception that is often propagated about PoV is brought about by the 24 or 30 f/s in film, and that's that the recovery time of human eyes is more or less constant. But what people need to realize is that the recovery time depends upon many factors such as contrast, incident light, etc. in movies they can get away with 24 f/s because each frame of the film is very similar to its neighbors. Higher contrast settings such as an alternating black and white screen require much higher frequencies, up to around 150 Hz, before our eyes see the average grey. At night, a bright LED can cause the image in our darkness-adjusted eyes to decay much more slowly which allows for this same effect to be (popularly) applied to bicycle tires, rotating at only a few revolutions per second. Good examples of this are a fluorescent light, although flashing at 120 Hz,  still appearing to flicker, and a camera flash in a dark room that can leave a noticeable white tint to our vision for many seconds after it goes off.

For someone who is into electronics, each unit of light sensitive material on the retina of our eyes acts like a tiny light sensor connected in series with a resistor that connects to our brain, with a capacitor between them, which is connected in parallel. The sensor charges up the capacitor quickly, to match the level of light it's exposed to, but when it's not exposed to light, the capacitor discharges relatively slowly through the resistor connected to our brain. And the capacitors have very high capacitance. That's why when you momentarily look into something very bright, like direct sunlight (even though you shouldn't), you'll keep seeing a negative image for a minute or two afterwards. And just like capacitors can blow when exposed to high voltages that they're not rated for, you can blow you eye's light sensors and capacitors by exposing them to high light levels for too long (e.g. looking into direct sunlight for too long) and go blind.

A PWM(Pulse Width Modulation) controller connected to an LED(s) is another easy way to see how slow our eyes are. LED's can't actually be dimmed so the PWM controls the "duty time" or percentage of time the LED is ON at a frequency that is relatively slow but fast enough that it appears to us that the LED is producing less light. When in reality the LED is just as bright but turning off and on very quickly.This is also a way to show just how insanely fast the clock speed is on even the slowest microprocessor.

The colors on the island has nothing to do with persistence of vision, but rather the sensivity of the rods in your eyes. It has to do with afterimages, rods getting used to a color and remembers them. The negative image becomes an afterimage, and overlays with the black and white - guess what happens when you overlay a negative color image over a black and white images? Yes! Color! The colors, however, will become desatured because the rods get less sensitive - to prevent over-exposure - the longer you see a particular color. That is why the image looks desatured from the original.

The reason why you see those colors on a black and white image is because the eye is pretty lazy. After you look at something for a long enough time without moving, the light receptors in your eye basically shut off, but your brain still knows what it is looking at. When the image changes, the receptors take a little bit before they turn back on, so you only see the colors that go with the receptors that haven't been turned off. If you look at something red for a really long time, then look at a white wall, you'll see a greenish outline, because all the red receptors are off, but the green ones are still working. Since the colors were inverted, your eyes got used to that image, when those inverted colors disappeared, the light receptors that were off stayed off, and so the receptors that would have been able to see the original colors were left on and they were the only colors you could see, if you did it right. If you had moved your eyes too much right before the transition, it wouldn't work.

Hello from Brazil, and congrats for ur great videos! I'm just fascinated for them!

Your cone cells are basically RGB pixels and can be photobleached. That is if you look at a red light the R-cones will use-up the active protein photopsin and the R-cones will become less sensitive to red (as so with green and blue light on the G and B cones). So if you stare at a color negative image the R, the G and the B photopsin will be reduced (photobleached) in proportion to the R, the G and B brightness and just opposite that if you where looking at the original positive. And then when you switch to the gray image the cones that were less bleached will send (relatively) more signal to your brain and so what was an orangie sky become bluie. But wait, the images was grey; remember that different shades of grey are made up of different intensities of equal proportions of RGB. So the blue is there and your now relatively more sensitive B cones dominate. I took the island image with the orangie sky to Photoshop and at approximately the center of the sky I measured a RGB value of 152, 92, 5 and in the blue (cyan) image 152, 172, 216. So the brightest color in one image becomes the (relatively) lowest and the dimmest colors become the brightest in the other image. Note that the R in both images is the same (152), I think this is because the inverted image (orangie sky) had its saturation and brightness bumped-up a bit (i.e. to produce a bigger impact of the cones). If you have Photoshop or similar try it with any color image.

Cheers,
Mark

First of all, what is the equation that came out to 0.04 on your laptop. And secondly, our eyes are seeing little gaps of no light at 30 fps. Think about it, the reason why we can see the difference between 30 and 60 fps so easily, is because of the amount of time that passes between each frame. We prefer 60 over 30 fps, because our eyes aren't seeing the gap as much , resulting in a smoother video. In fact our eye can't detect any more "smoothness" past 60 fps. In a lot of competitive video games, people prefer better frames than they do graphics. If an animated character moves across the screen( and you're viewing this at 30 fps) you will see 50% less of that character, making it harder to shoot him. Consequently 60 fps gives you the ability to view more of him faster.

Once upon a time I was a security supervisor at an installation where security was taken seriously. When it was foggy the black & white monitors displaying images of high interest areas would show an almost solid block of gray mist even when the camera lenses were clean and dry. Even after the fog or mist had almost cleared so a human (put in place to temporary replace the degraded mechanical view) could easily see along the entire area the remote monitor covered. I do not remember any difference in how the fog disrupted the display between night and day.

After studying the monitors and then going into the field to see for myself the clarity of vision humans had compared to the monitors I hypothesized the monitors were literal in their display of the data they received from the cameras. I thought the monitors displayed every droplet in the mist in a two dimensional manner along the length of view. So the monitors added up all the droplets existing in the infinitesimal slices(?) of the camera's collection of data causing the monitor to display a solid misty view.

I figured why the same length of space with slight mistiness seemed relatively clear to human sight was due to our brains doing some processing to see through or around the areas containing droplets.

Although I was curious; it was before the great internet and time prevented me from driving to a library to research the phenomenon. I will be reading up on Dr. Stuart Anstis' visual perception papers! Thanks for the tip Dustin.

I'd just like the point out. you are wrong about your statement that we would see flicker at "less than 24 fps".

The reason, is that our mobile and PC displays are actually full persistence displays, so there can't be any flicker.

However, this introduces motion blur. And is also not ideal. So right now, since we can't have 1000hz displays, the best solution seems to have "low persistence" displays. by strobing the backlight.

In PC monitors we have "lightboost" to accomplish this, in CRT's we already had this naturally, and in something like the Oculus rift they do this by turning the OLED on and off as fast as they can. (75 hz hz for DK2, 90hz for CV1)

Btw, if you wanna see this effect "in action" for yourself, look at a small, blinking led. As the receptors in the middle of your eye are slower, the blinking will be fading in and out if you're looking at the led directly. The receptors that are placed more outside have evolved to be registering slight movements where you don't look directly, so they're less accurate but a lot faster - look next to the led - so that you can barely see it, and you will notice it's blinking not only a lot faster but it also doesn't fade in or out - it'll just change from on to off.

And to explain the introducing illusion (with an inverted-colours image changing to B&W), it happens because when we look at certain colours for a prolonged period of time, the corresponding pigments in our eye cells become bleached. Basically, when you stare at red colour for some time, the red pigment in the eye cells gets bleached out, increasing your sensitivity to cyan (the opposite of red). Thus, when the red part of an image turns to a shade of grey, your eyes see cyan colour in its place. Blue parts are seen as yellow, and green parts as magenta. This is not so much due to your brain, as the actual eye cell funtion which tries to balance or compensate for what you see.
our eyes are sort of digital, because it's individual cones and rods, but our nervous system is analog.

Destin, in 1967 a scenic designer named Joseph Svoboda created a projection sceen using a spinning hoop about 6' across. The edge was painted white, but the hoop had nothing on the inside, so the audience could see it was just an empty circlehanging inthe air. Then they saw it start to spin, and when it hit the  correct revolutions per minute, there was a film projecting on it thanks to the persistence of vision effect you described in the video. I bet you could reproduce this effect in an experiment.

It'd be interesting to contemplate the chemistry behind the illusion.  For example, how do the photons striking the atoms in the retina affect them, presumably chemically?  Perhaps vision persistence is related to the number of ions (the volume or mass...think micromoles per second or similar) which can flow/move per unit of time to the cells being impacted by photons.  Perhaps they continue to flow after the light is extinguished until chemical balance returns, and continues to send the "signal" down the nerve cell.  Also, electrically it is rare that waveforms are perfectly square, there is always at least minute amounts of capacitance and inductance in real circuits which resist change in voltage or current levels (although it is often very, very close to instantaneous, because capacitance for example is very small)...thus the LED may get to full brightness over a very small but finite time.

to be fair these gaps in time when you see the light is the effect of your photoreceptor cells going down after being "pinged" by light (this is done in a bool style, as there is very high number of them, and they are very small, the brightness is statistic amount of photoreceptor cells hit by the blast of light). Because of the way eyes and cameras are build <or grown> certain part of "screen " (the image you see), are sending light to the specific area of your photoreceptor cells, so this means that one "arcxel" actually lights again and again receptors in the same area over and over again. The thing is that this is how regular screens work <i'm 100% sure about the old big ones, not sure about lcd screen>. On screen only one from 1,9 * 10^3* 0,8 * 10^3 is sending light at time. Of course lcd have some cooldown time but it's nothing compared to the delay of human eyes. And there is more. The truth is that  lcd screen make brightness by flashing. This means that if you want make 010000<close to black, just a little bit red> the lcd has to blink only for 1/256 time it actually should. So you want color 010000 for one frame it means that the lcd will be shining for you just for about  6,5 * 10^(-5)  sec, which is about 65 micro seconds (0,000065 sec). Insane.

I remember reading that the chemicals in your eyes get depleted if they are used too much in a short period. E.g. if you sun bathe with your eyes closed, enjoying the red of your eye lids, at some point you start to see blue and when you open your eyes you see the world in a blue-ish tone because your eye-cells that are sensitive to red are exhausted.
