i notice every little thing, like your explanation about why we see color on the island being off.

we see colors not because our brains fill it automatically, rather because the inverted colors get "burned" on our retina. Everyone should know our eye adapts to luminosity, but what some seem not to understand is that it adapts on a per-color basis. we have 3 different types of cones (Red green a blue), so when one of them, say, the green one, gets exposed to a lot of light, it gets inhibited a bit to lower luminosity, and as a result you'll see less green in the image, and consequently, proportionally more of the two other colors (which results in a pink-ish after-image wherever the green was). that's why when you close one eye in bright sunlight, everything seems blue-ish and compared to the other eye that you kept open (that's just the after effect of you adapting to the red of your closed eyelids)

stare long enough into a image and you'll see its inverted afterimage after a little while (it'll get "burned" into your eye by the process above)
invert the colors of the original image before staring into it, and the after-image will be inverted again, which gets us back to the original colors. Then, if you overlay that part of your vision on top a black and white image, will seem to tint it slightly with the "original" colors. that's why you have to have a fixed point to stare into, or this doesn't work at all.
btw, you can increase the saturation and contrast of the inverted image you stare at to make the effect a lot stronger.

8:16 : Actually we wouldn't see image flickering today with lower framerate because most of recent LCD screens use high latency LEDs => the screen display a black image very shortly compared to the "colored" period.
Therefore the lower framerate would result in a less-smooth feeling but not a flickering.

But this effect would be true on older screens or in movie theaters. ;)

Another thing : the sensation of smooth movements on videos doesn't come from the retinal persistance (it helps only to not see the void/black) but mostly from the brain that recreates the illussion of continuous momentum. That's why it works even on low framerate animation like cartoons (usually ~12FPS).

Now, it's my turn to share with you... The following is a perfect example of persistence of vision, and trust me, you will not believe your eyes when you try this.

Take a flash bulb into a completely dark room or closet, face the bulb away from you and ignite it. You will see everything in the room for several seconds until the image fades. The brighter the flash is the better the image will look and longer it will last. Try flashing your hand in front of you. You will be amazed at the level of detail you will see in your hand. An even more amazing thing is that you can move your head around after the initial flash and you see all the features of the room, even behind you. Just Kidding :) The image moves with your head which is a freaky feeling.

I first discovered this in 1982 (age 12) and I did it 1000s of times and loved showing my friends the effect. I used the old external camera flash from a 35mm.

BTW: that spinning LED project has been around for many years, in many flavors. There is even a cheap Chinese fan with embedded LEDs doing the same thing. About 15 years ago I bought a clock that had about 10 LEDs on a pendulum. When it was swinging, it would display the time on every sweep. You can also spin a row of LEDs vertically around a vertical axis to form a column like a can and create an image on the outer surface of the can. If you rotate an array (x,y) of LEDs around any axis through the array, you can create a "REAL" 3d image because at any given point in time an LED occupies every position in space within the shape that is created during rotation.

I learned it as the flicker fusion rate (or threshold), but the first optical illusion, the "negative afterimage" is the cones in your eyes becoming fatigued, normally your eyes move a tiny bit to counter this, but because the image is so close that doesn't work. When you switch to the black and white image the cells around the tired ones are sending a normal signal, but the tired cones are sending a weak signal so the opponent system overpowers it and we get a "negative afterimage". Our eyes have a lot of opponent systems, blue-yellow, red-green, etc SO: when you defeat eye flutter with the big photo you wear out red receptors and then you get 'green' signal.

As an animator, that works in FPS every day. I would say the persistence of vision of the eye is a bit slower than you suggested. We often work on "twos" with would equate to 12 frames per second.
And although it's a tiny bit less smooth. No one ever complains that it doesn't look like continuous motion.
(Animators have been using this frame rate for many years)

You can get away with much slower frame rate than most people expect and the eye/brain Nions up all the dots for you nicely.

As to games often needing 60fps these days this has more to do with latency or "lag" in the input controls, than in persistence of vision.

7 segment displays make use of persistence of vision as well. You see a number but in reality only one segment in the display is illuminated at any moment. In fact, you can kind of see this with the naked eye if you're willing to do something that might make you look stupid to those around you. If you hum at the same frequency as the display, the segments will bounce around in your vision. It can be fun trying to find the right frequency.

comment_text: Had you not given your explanation for seeing color on that image of the island I would have explained it like this: The original image was in color and after staring at any color for a period the brain reverses those colors when given a blank image in place of it. The monochrome image of the island acted as a canvas upon which the reversed colors were painted (superimposed) making it appear like the monochrome image was in color.
